Authors: Ishaq M., Masud H.
Title: Congenital glaucoma and penetrating keratoplasty failure in De Sanctis-Cacchione syndrome
Source title: Journal of the College of Physicians and Surgeons Pakistan
Affiliations: Department of Ophthalmology, Military Hospital, Rawalpindi, Pakistan
Authors with affiliations: Ishaq, M., Department of Ophthalmology, Military Hospital, Rawalpindi, Pakistan; Masud, H., Department of Ophthalmology, Military Hospital, Rawalpindi, Pakistan
Abstract: De Sanctis-Cacchione Syndrome is an extremely rare disorder inherited as an autosomal recessive genetic trait and characterised by xeroderma pigmentosum, mental retardation, dwarfism and hypogonadism. We report two cases of De Sanctis-Cacchione syndrome, one with congenital glaucoma which is being reported in literature for the first time and the second with penetrating keratoplasty failure. Management of De Sanctis-Cacchione syndrome is difficult and requires multidisciplinary approach. Ophthalmologists are advised to check intraocular pressure of all the patients diagnosed as De Sanctis - Cacchione syndrome to avoid potential blindness due to glaucoma.

Authors: Kwok S.K., Ho P.C.P., Chau G.K.O.
Title: Herpes zoster ophthalmicus - A family physician's perspective
Affiliations: 28 Yee Woo Street, Causeway Bay, Hong Kong
Authors with affiliations: Kwok, S.K., 28 Yee Woo Street, Causeway Bay, Hong Kong; Ho, P.C.P., 28 Yee Woo Street, Causeway Bay, Hong Kong; Chau, G.K.O., 28 Yee Woo Street, Causeway Bay, Hong Kong
Abstract: Herpes zoster is commonly encountered by family physicians. Herpes zoster ophthalmicus (HZO) is of special interest because it is a potentially blinding disease if left untreated. It is amongst the commonest cause of corneal scarring and secondary uveitis in ophthalmic practice. The role of primary care physicians is important because antiviral therapy is most effective with treatment begun within 72 hours of onset of rash. The purpose of this article is to address the diagnostic dilemma faced by family physicians and to discuss the various aspects of treatment.

Abstract: A study was carried out to evaluate the effect of hemodynamic changes on the photopic flash oscillatory potentials (OPs) and electroretinogram (fERG) in man. 15 healthy adults participated in 2 test sessions to examine the effect of breathing. A gas mask was used throughout the test session. The heart rate (HR), respiratory rate (RR), oxygen saturation (SaO2) and end-tidal CO2 (EtCO2) were recorded continuously. Title: The impact of information technology on the practice of ophthalmology

Abstract: Information technology has had a tremendous impact on the outlook of our professional lives. The Internet has revolutionised the speed of access to information with touch of a button. This article discusses the various aspects of information technology which are changing and enhancing our professional lives. It provides tips to enable the busy practising clinician to use the available resources effectively. Problems such as reliability of information on the web and how to assess the quality of such matter are also discussed.

Authors: Bartel P., Roux P., Van Niekerk M.
Title: Vitamin A status in relation to electroretinographic and electrooculographic findings in HIV infection
Affiliations: Department of Neurology, Pretoria Acad. Hosp. Univ. Pretoria, Pretoria, South Africa; Department of Ophthalmology, Pretoria Acad. Hosp. Univ. Pretoria, Pretoria, South Africa
Authors with affiliations: Bartel, P., Department of Neurology, Pretoria Acad. Hosp. Univ. Pretoria, Pretoria, South Africa; Roux, P., Department of Ophthalmology, Pretoria Acad. Hosp. Univ. Pretoria, Pretoria, South Africa; Van Niekerk, M., Department of Neurology, Pretoria Acad. Hosp. Univ. Pretoria, Pretoria, South Africa
Abstract: Objectives: To investigate the electrooculogram (EOG) and an expanded battery of electroretinograms (ERGs) in HIV-infected subjects without retinopathy at two different levels of immunosuppression. Consideration was given to the possible effects of serum levels of vitamin A. Methods: Two groups of neurologically normal HIV-positive subjects with CD4+ cell counts of <200 (n=17) or >400 (n=19) were contrasted with 20 HIV-negative controls. Rod ERGs, oscillatory potentials and cone ERGs were obtained using ganzfeld stimulation. A sequence of dark- and light-adapted EOG recordings was analyzed to obtain light/dark ratios. The HIV-positive subjects underwent a comprehensive ophthalmologic examination. Results: Intergroup comparisons failed to reveal any significant intergroup differences. Abnormal ERG findings, those exceeding the 98% confidence limits, occurred in 11% (4/36) of the HIV-positive subjects. One of these subjects was hyporetinemic and another had a subnormal retinol level. No subjects had abnormal EOGs. Conclusions: HIV infection influenced retinal function in 11% of a group of neurologically normal subjects without clinical signs of retinopathy. The profile of electrophysiological findings suggested predominant functional deficits involving middle or inner retinal layers. Vitamin A deficiency and possible vascular changes could account for the observed ERG abnormalities. Copyright (C) 2000 Elsevier Science Ireland Ltd.
Author Keywords: Electrooculogram; Electroretinogram; HIV; Vitamin A

Authors: Sankeralli M.J., Chen J.C., Metha A.B., Mullen K.T.
Title: Evidence for mild blue-yellow colour vision deficits immediately following fluorescein angiography
Affiliations: McGill Vision Research, Department of Ophthalmology, McGill University, Montreal, Que. H3A 1A1, Canada; McGill Retina Unit, Department of Ophthalmology, McGill University, Montreal, Que. H3A 1A1, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Sankeralli, M.J., McGill Vision Research, Department of Ophthalmology, McGill University, Montreal, Que. H3A 1A1, Canada; Chen, J.C., McGill Retina Unit, Department of Ophthalmology, McGill University, Montreal, Que. H3A 1A1, Canada; Metha, A.B., McGill Vision Research, Department of Ophthalmology, McGill University, Montreal, Que. H3A 1A1, Canada; Mullen, K.T., McGill Vision Research, Department of Ophthalmology, McGill University, Montreal, Que. H3A 1A1, Canada
Abstract: Aims: We have investigated the short term effects of fluorescein angiography on the blue-yellow, red-green, and luminance contrast sensitivity of patients with early age-related macular degeneration (ARMD). Methods: Nine ARMD patients with no exudative complications and a visual acuity of 20/60 or better in the tested eye were selected. Cardinal colour directions for the isolation of the red-green, blue-yellow and achromatic (luminance) visual mechanisms were determined for each patient. Contrast sensitivity was measured in each cardinal colour direction immediately before and 20 min after standard 20-flash fluorescein angiography. Results: A significant, albeit mild, reduction for blue-yellow contrast sensitivity following angiography was observed (ANOVA, α=0.05). Fluorescein angiographic exposure had no significant effect on red-green or luminance contrast sensitivity. Conclusion: Our results show that fluorescein angiography causes at least a short term deficit selective to blue-yellow contrast sensitivity in our patient group. (C) 2000 The College of Optometrists.

Authors: Asbury T.
Title: A condensed history of ophthalmology in Cincinnati (1827-1999)
Affiliations: Department of Ophthalmology, Univ. of Cincinnati Coll. of Med., Cincinnati, OH, United States
Authors with affiliations: Asbury, T., Department of Ophthalmology, Univ. of Cincinnati Coll. of Med., Cincinnati, OH, United States
Abstract: The history of ophthalmology in Cincinnati dates back to 1827, when Dr. Daniel Drake founded the Eye Institute of Cincinnati. Since that time, many other individuals have influenced the course of ophthalmology in the city and region. Included among these were Elkanah Williams, first chairman of the Department of Ophthalmology at Miami Medical College of Ohio (the forerunner of the University of Cincinnati), William Seeley, Robert Sattler, Christian Holmes, Derrick T. Vail and his illustrious son Derrick T. Vail, Jr., Clarence King, Karl Ascher, Donald Lyle, and Mary Knight Asbury. The author presents brief biographical summaries and interesting anecdotes about each of these individuals and several others of importance to Cincinnati ophthalmology. Copyright (C) 2000 Elsevier Science Inc.

Authors: Jenchitr W.T., Tansirikongkol V.
Title: Ophthalmology in Thailand 1997
Source title: Journal of the Medical Association of Thailand
Affiliations: Central Co-ordinating Committee, Natl. Comm. for the Prev. of Blindn., Ministry of Public Health, Nonthaburi 11000, Thailand
Authors with affiliations: Jenchitr, W.T., Central Co-ordinating Committee, Natl. Comm. for the Prev. of Blindn., Ministry of Public Health, Nonthaburi 11000, Thailand; Tansirikongkol, V., Central Co-ordinating Committee, Natl. Comm. for the Prev. of Blindn., Ministry of Public Health, Nonthaburi 11000, Thailand
Abstract: This article is a brief history of ophthalmology in Thailand after World War II and the National Programmes for the Prevention of Blindness in the past two decades from the late 1970's. Presentation illustrates the efforts of the eye sector in Thailand not only modernizing ophthalmology. However, eye care services in public places has also been made available to all assured with easy accessibility and acceptable quality. The National Blindness Prevention programmes have been forwarded through adoption of primary eye care approach integrating into the national health scheme of primary health care. Avoidable blindness once prevalent in 1980's, has been reduced from 1.1 per cent to 0.3 per cent in twenty years. Eye care networks that came into existence in that period covering the whole country are now once again under realignment for new challenges from unavoidable types of blindness.

Title: Bulbar conjunctival folds in patients with moderately dry eyes
Affiliations: Univ of Houston, Houston, TX, United States
Authors with affiliations: Patel, Sangita, Univ of Houston, Houston, TX, United States; Miller, William L., Univ of Houston, Houston, TX, United States; Narayanan, Srihari, Univ of Houston, Houston, TX, United States; Quintero, Sam, Univ of Houston, Houston, TX, United States; Jackson, Julie, Univ of Houston, Houston, TX, United States; Leach, Norman, Univ of Houston, Houston, TX, United States; Bergmanson, Jan P.G., Univ of Houston, Houston, TX, United States
Abstract: A study was made to correlate and compare the presence of temporal bulbar conjunctival folds with the Phenol Red Thread Test, Schirmer's Test, limbal injection, and bulbar injection in subjects with a history of moderately dry eyes. All data were collected under ambient conditions. Bulbar conjunctival folds showed a mild positive correlation with Schirmer's test. A negative correlation was evident between the folds and limbal injection. No significant correlation was seen with the radial folds and bulbar injection or the Phenol Red Thread test.

Authors: Wren Valerie Q., Krumholz David M., Portello Joan K., Rosenfield Mark, Rosenbaum Jacob D.
Title: Effectiveness of cycloplegia and pupillary dilation with cyclopentolate, tropicamide and phenylephrine in a single combination solution
Affiliations: State Univ of New York, New York, NY, United States
Authors with affiliations: Wren, Valerie Q., State Univ of New York, New York, NY, United States; Krumholz, David M., State Univ of New York, New York, NY, United States; Portello, Joan K., State Univ of New York, New York, NY, United States; Rosenfield, Mark, State Univ of New York, New York, NY, United States; Rosenbaum, Jacob D., State Univ of New York, New York, NY, United States
Abstract: The onset, magnitude and duration of cycloplegia and mydriasis using a combination drop were studied. One eye of each subject was dilated with one drop of the 'control' solution containing 1% cyclopentolate. The other eye was dilated with a combination solution containing 0.5% tropicamide and 1% cyclopentolate. Every 15 minutes for three hours, the accommodative amplitude was measured by the push-up method, and a photograph including both pupils was taken. It was observed that a single solution containing 0.5% tropicamide and 1% cyclopentolate is clinically effective for routine pupil dilation and cycloplegic examinations.

Abstract: Shakespeare's play Measure for Measure colorfully illustrates a concept that is relevant to the testimonies given by the medical expert witness in the courtroom. The expert should not ask the jury to hold the defendant physician to a higher standard than that actually practiced by an acceptable reasonable minority of the defendant's peers under similar circumstances. Authors: Villalobos T., McMahon M.C., Rathore M.H.
Title: Recurrent periorbital zosteriform herpes simplex virus infection in childhood
Affiliations: Division of Pediatric Infectious Diseases and Immunology, University of Florida, Health Science Center, Jacksonville, FL, United States; Nemours Children's Clinic, Jacksonville, FL, United States; Wolfson Children's Hospital, Jacksonville, FL, United States
Authors with affiliations: Villalobos, T., Division of Pediatric Infectious Diseases and Immunology, University of Florida, Health Science Center, Jacksonville, FL, United States; McMahon, M.C., Division of Pediatric Infectious Diseases and Immunology, University of Florida, Health Science Center, Jacksonville, FL, United States; Rathore, M.H., Division of Pediatric Infectious Diseases and Immunology, University of Florida, Health Science Center, Jacksonville, FL, United States, Nemours Children's Clinic, Jacksonville, FL, United States, Wolfson Children's Hospital, Jacksonville, FL, United States
Abstract: Introduction. Zosteriform herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection is an uncommon presentation of HSV recurrent cutaneous infection and it is usually misdiagnosed as zoster. Methods. We report a series of consecutive cases of zosteriform HSV that we recently managed. Results. Four cases of recurrent zosteriform HSV infection in the second division of the trigeminal nerve were seen. Immunologic evaluation determined that the patients were immunocompetent. Culture and/or direct fluorescent stain diagnosed HSV. No ocular involvement was present, and all patients responded to oral acyclovir. Recommendations. Clinicians should suspect HSV infection in patients with recurrent vesicular lesions with zosteriform appearance. Immunologic evaluation is not necessary; however, ophthalmologic examination to exclude ocular involvement is required. Oral acyclovir is useful for treatment.
Author Keywords: Children; Cutaneous HSV infection; Recurrent; Zoster

Authors: Dyer A.M., Kirk A.H.
Title: A fully automated remote refraction system.
Affiliations: Calgary Regional Health Authority, Department of Ophthalmology, Alberta, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Dyer, A.M., Calgary Regional Health Authority, Department of Ophthalmology, Alberta, Canada; Kirk, A.H., Calgary Regional Health Authority, Department of Ophthalmology, Alberta, Canada
Abstract: Traditional methods of performing refractions depend on a trained refractionist being present with the subject and conducting an interactive form of subjective testing. A fully automated refraction system was installed in 13 optical dispensaries and after 15 months the patient and statistical information was gathered. The data from all operators were consistent and suggested a lack of operator effect on the refraction results. The mean of the SD of subjective sphere measurements was 0.2, or slightly less than a quarter dioptre, which would be an acceptable level of accuracy for ordering corrective lenses. The present study suggests an absence of operator influence on the results of the refractions and a degree of consistency and accuracy compatible with the prescription of lenses.

Title: Fluorescein-assisted viscondissection for easier phacoemulsification
Affiliations: Ophthalmology Department, Cairo University, Cairo, Egypt

Abstract: Title: Fluorescein-assisted viscodissection for easier phacoemulsification. Settings: Department of Ophthalmology, Cairo University. Purpose: The description of a new surgical technique to help overcome difficulties in the learning curve of phacoemulsification. Methods: A mixture of Fluorescein 0.25% and methyl cellulose 0.25% is used for hydrodissection. Standard phacoemulsification is then continued until the initial groove reaches the plane between the lens cortex and the capsule when the fluorescein flows towards the anterior chamber in a Green Smoke. This sign indicates a proper depth for attempting to crack the nucleus into two halves.

Authors: Bindlish V.
Title: What the ophthalmologist should know about sinus disease
Affiliations: Mount Sinai Hospital, University of Toronto, 600 University Avenue, Toronto, Ont., Canada
Authors with affiliations: Bindlish, V., Mount Sinai Hospital, University of Toronto, 600 University Avenue, Toronto, Ont., Canada
Abstract: Purpose: The aim of this article is to familiarize the practicing ophthalmologist with common diseases of the paranasal sinuses, and with the ways these diseases affect the orbit. Methods: This review article covers the basic anatomy and physiology of the sinuses, followed by a discussion of disease states - acute sinusitis, chronic sinusitis, nasal polyposis, mucoceles, and benign and malignant neoplasms. Results: Recommended management of the above-mentioned disease states, including endoscopic sinus surgery and associated complications, are presented. Conclusion: Diseases affecting the paranasal sinuses are common and affect a large proportion of the population. Due to the close proximity of the sinuses to the orbit(s), inflammatory or neoplastic disease frequently presents with orbital symptoms and/or signs. It is therefore important for ophthalmologists to be familiar with these diseases.

Authors: Bullock J.D.
Title: Post hoc, ergo propter hoc
Affiliations: Department of Ophthalmology, Wright State University, School of Medicine, Dayton, OH, United States; 500 Lincoln Park Blvd., Dayton, OH 45429-3487, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bullock, J.D., Department of Ophthalmology, Wright State University, School of Medicine, Dayton, OH, United States, 500 Lincoln Park Blvd., Dayton, OH 45429-3487, United States
Abstract: Three cases are described in which patients sought damages for retinal detachments that followed minor trauma. In fact, the traumatic incidents were not responsible for the detachments. Criteria for diagnosing traumatic retinal detachments are summarized, and ophthalmologists and attorneys are cautioned to be wary of post hoc reasoning. © 2001 Elsevier Science Inc.

Authors: Akura J., Hatta S., Kaneda S., Matsuura K., Tamai A., Kadonosono K.
Title: Guided knives
Affiliations: Kushimoto Rehabilitation Center, Kushimoto, Japan; Department of Ophthalmology, Faculty of Medicine, Tottori University, Yonago, Japan; Department of Ophthalmology, Yokohama City University, School of Medicine, Yokohama, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Akura, J., Kushimoto Rehabilitation Center, Kushimoto, Japan; Hatta, S., Department of Ophthalmology, Faculty of Medicine, Tottori University, Yonago, Japan; Kaneda, S., Kushimoto Rehabilitation Center, Kushimoto, Japan; Matsuura, K., Department of Ophthalmology, Faculty of Medicine, Tottori University, Yonago, Japan; Tamai, A., Department of Ophthalmology, Faculty of Medicine, Tottori University, Yonago, Japan; Kadonosono, K., Department of Ophthalmology, Yokohama City University, School of Medicine, Yokohama, Japan
Abstract: A new type of knife that enables a surgeon to easily create tunnel-shaped incisions with a prescribed depth has been developed. The knife features an incision guide, the arm of which extends just beyond the tip of the blade. The space between the blade and the arm can be set at the desired width. By moving the knife as if sliding the arm across the corneal or scleral surface, the blade can move to a certain depth from the surface. The guided knife enables even novice surgeons to easily make a self-sealing incision during cataract surgery. In addition, the innovative nature of this device seems to be applicable to many other surgeries that require a partial-thickness incision.

Authors: Winstanley J.
Title: Dr. William Briggs: ophthalmic physician at St. Thomas' Hospital, London.
Affiliations: St. Thomas' Hospital, London, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Winstanley, J., St. Thomas' Hospital, London, United Kingdom
Abstract: William Briggs, MD, established himself as one of the first ophthalmic physicians, whom today we would call a neuro-ophthalmologist, to practice in the United Kingdom. After graduating with an MD from Cambridge in 1677, and while a Fellow of Corpus Christi College, he carried out original studies in visual anatomy and physiology. He described and named the optic papilla and the retinal nerve fibers in his book Ophthalmographia, published in 1676. He published his New Theory of Vision in 1682. While at Cambridge, he was a contemporary and a friend of Isaac Newton, with whom Briggs worked but who, in matters of visual anatomy and physiology, came to reach different conclusions from Briggs. In 1683, Briggs came to London to practice as a physician at St. Thomas' Hospital, where he established a considerable reputation as an ophthalmologist. For political reasons he was forced to resign from the Hospital prematurely.
Index Keywords: art; article; history; hospital; ophthalmology; physician; United Kingdom; History, 17th Century; History, 18th Century; Hospitals; London; Ophthalmology; Physicians; Portraits

Authors: Kessler D.M.
Title: Wills Eye Hospital and surgical network: successful pre-positioning strategies for payment reduction and managed care pressures.
Affiliations: Wills Eye Hospital, Philadelphia, USA.
Authors with affiliations: Kessler, D.M., Wills Eye Hospital, Philadelphia, USA.
Abstract: Through strategic clinical diversification, political activism, and bold expansion, Wills Eye Hospital, a teaching specialty surgical hospital, survives ravages of sudden onslaughts of managed care payment reductions while maintaining autonomy. Slack inpatient resources were re-utilized to create unique programs attractive to regional managed care organizations. Advocacy and lobbying for short-term favorable treatment from Medicare bought the Hospital valuable time and positioning. Building out a regional network of ambulatory surgical centers assures the growth and access to market required for Wills to maintain its autonomy in a managed care contracting environment.

Authors: Soroka M., Rosenthal J., Wende J.
Title: Eye care providers in managed care.
Affiliations: Center for Vision Care Policy, State College of Optometry, State University of New York, New York City, United States
Authors with affiliations: Soroka, M., Center for Vision Care Policy, State College of Optometry, State University of New York, New York City, United States; Rosenthal, J., Center for Vision Care Policy, State College of Optometry, State University of New York, New York City, United States; Wende, J., Center for Vision Care Policy, State College of Optometry, State University of New York, New York City, United States
Abstract: The integrated relationship and roles in managed care of ophthalmologists, optometrists, and opticians have changed profoundly in recent years. The change is in part the result of the advancement of optometric education and license in the diagnosis and treatment of ocular disease. The change has also evolved because of the influence of managed care and its objective to reduce costs while elevating quality of care. The authors explain that vertical integration of all ophthalmic services, ranging from eye examination to eyeglass dispensing to ocular surgery, can help MCOs maximize quality and minimize costs.

Authors: Shah Y., Syed K.R.R., Hafiz A.
Title: Isolation of bacteria associated with dacryocystitis
Source title: Journal of the College of Physicians and Surgeons Pakistan
Affiliations: Department of Pathology, Sindh Medical College, Karachi, Pakistan
Authors with affiliations: Shah, Y., Department of Pathology, Sindh Medical College, Karachi, Pakistan; Syed, K.R.R., Department of Pathology, Sindh Medical College, Karachi, Pakistan; Hafiz, A., Department of Pathology, Sindh Medical College, Karachi, Pakistan
Abstract: Objective: To isolate and culture bacterial flora associated with diseased and normal lacrimal sacs along with its sensitivity against common antibiotics. Design: Lacrimal sac swabs and aspirated contents of diseased sacs were analyzed in a microbiology laboratory. Place and Duration: The study was conducted at Jinnah Postgraduate Medical Center (JPMC), and Microbiology Department, Dr. Tahir's Laboratory, Hamdard University Hospital, Taj Medical Complex, Karachi from September 1997 to December 1998. Patients/Methods: Samples collected from 100 patients of dacryocystitis (group-A) who underwent dacryocystectomy or dacryocystorhinostomy at JPMC, Karachi and 50 normal cases (group-B) were processed for isolation of different bacterial species. The sensitivity pattern of isolated bacteria from both the groups was compared. Results: Bacteria isolated from group-A were Strep. pneumoniae from 21, Klebsiella pneumoniae from 8 and Strep. viridans, Enterobacter aerogenes, corynebacterium, proteus and pseudomonas species from 2 cases each, whereas lacrimal sacs of group-B were positive for Klebsiella pneumoniae in 15, E. coli in 2, Strep. pneumoniae and pseudomonas one in each cases. Strep. pneumoniae was isolated in a significantly higher number from the patients of dacryocystitis, while Klebsiella pneumoniae was significantly high in group-B cases. Bacteria encountered in dacryocystitis were resistant in majority to commonly used antibiotics i.e., ampicillin, chloramphenicol and tetracycline but sensitive to vancomycin, kanamycin and gentamycin. Conclusion: A continuous bacteriologic surveillance to identify common etiological agents along with its sensitivity is imperative. The ophthalmologists should be aware that about 50% preoperative patients without signs of ocular infection may have bacterial infection. We emphasize that the antibiotic therapy should be initiated on receipt of culture sensitivity report from a Microbiological laboratory since the antibiotic sensitivity of bacteria is largely unpredictable and multiresistant strains are common.
Author Keywords: Dacryocystitis; Dacryocystorhinostomy; Drug sensitivity assay, microbial; Etiology; Infection; Kleb.pneumoniae; Strep.pneumoniae

Authors: Akram I., Akram A.
Title: Systemic disorders presenting to the ophthalmologist
Source title: Journal of the College of Physicians and Surgeons Pakistan
Affiliations: Eye Department, Luton and Dunstable Hospital, Lewsey Road, Luton, Beds LU4 0DZ, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Akram, I., Eye Department, Luton and Dunstable Hospital, Lewsey Road, Luton, Beds LU4 0DZ, United Kingdom; Akram, A., Eye Department, Luton and Dunstable Hospital, Lewsey Road, Luton, Beds LU4 0DZ, United Kingdom
Abstract: Ophthalmologists are uniquely placed among clinicians in being able to directly visualise various vascular and inflammatory conditions involving the blood vessels of the eye through the ocular media. Although common systemic disorders like diabetes, hypertension and various arthritides frequently involve the eye, very occasionally a patient harbouring an occult systemic condition may first present to an ophthalmologist with symptoms related to eye involvement rather than symptoms from the systemic disorder. Two examples are quoted here in its support. In both middle-aged men presented with unilateral decrease in vision without any other complaint. One of them was later found to be diabetic and the other was ultimately diagnosed as having pancreatic carcinoma.

Authors: Etufugh N.N., Glickman R.
Title: Correlation of computerized tomography and flat film radiographic findings with clinical examination in patients sustaining periorbital trauma
Affiliations: Nassau Oral and Maxillofacial Surg., 33 Front Street, Hempstead, NY 11550, United States
Authors with affiliations: Etufugh, N.N., Nassau Oral and Maxillofacial Surg., 33 Front Street, Hempstead, NY 11550, United States; Glickman, R., Nassau Oral and Maxillofacial Surg., 33 Front Street, Hempstead, NY 11550, United States
Abstract: Background and Objectives. When patients arrive at an emergency center with periorbital trauma, flat film radiographs are taken routinely - they are less costly than computerized tomography (CT) scans. When flat film radiographs are combined with preoperative CT scans, a complete representation is obtained preoperatively, enabling the selection of optimal treatment. A retrospective review of the data in patient charts was performed in a large city hospital center in order to evaluate the results. Methods and Materials. Charts of 164 patients who received trauma-related CT scans were evaluated, using the following procedures: ophthalmologic evaluation, examination of hard and soft tissues, examination of the cranial nerves, and neurologic examination. Results and/or Conclusions. In the group in whom flat film had recorded negative findings, 21 of 32 patients had positive CT findings. Orbital fractures were the most commonly involved. The lamina papyracea and orbital floor fractures received the most benefit from the use of CT scans, followed by lateral sinuses and nasoethmoidal fractures. The authors concluded that patients with periorbital trauma benefit from preoperative CT scans.
Author Keywords: Computerized tomography; Periorbital trauma
Index Keywords: article; clinical examination; computer assisted tomography; controlled study; correlation analysis; diagnostic value; human; major clinical study; neurologic examination; ophthalmology; orbit fracture; orbit injury; priority journal; radiography

Authors: Al-Makadma A.K.
Title: Familial hypomagnesemiahypercalciurea with nephro calcinosis and high myopia
Affiliations: Department of Pediatrics, Habib Medical Centre, P.O. Box 91877, Riyadh 11643, Saudi Arabia
Authors with affiliations: Al-Makadma, A.K., Department of Pediatrics, Habib Medical Centre, P.O. Box 91877, Riyadh 11643, Saudi Arabia
Abstract: Many disorders of hypomagnesemia of renal origin are now recognized. Familial hypomagnesemia, hypercalciuria and nephrocalcinosis is one of them. Few patients with this disorder have been described in literature. Two sisters from a consanguineous marriage with this syndrome are presented. Bilateral nephrocalcinosis was observed in both of them, interestingly one of them had a horse shoe kidney. The Glomerular filtration rate in both of them was decreased. The urinary calcium and magnesium were high in both of them where as urinary excretion of uric acid and oxalate were normal. Serum magnesium was low in both of them (0.2-0.4 mmol/L) but serum calcium, phosphorus and potassium were normal. Serum parathormone levels were abnormally high. Ophthalmological examination revealed that they had severe myopia with no other eye abnormalities.
Author Keywords: Familial hypomagnesemia; Hypercalciurea; Nephrocalcinosis; Severe myopia

Affiliations: New England Coll of Optometry, Boston, United States
Authors with affiliations: Farra, T., New England Coll of Optometry, Boston, United States; Brujic, M., New England Coll of Optometry, Boston, United States; Krenzer, K., New England Coll of Optometry, Boston, United States
Abstract: A study was carried out to determine the prevalence of disease detected during the New England College of Optometry (NEWENCO) student organized Volunteer Optometric Services to Humanity (VOSH) mission to Merida, Mexico. Data from 1000 consecutive patients (1999 eyes) were analyzed retrospectively out of a total of 3492 patients seen over a 6 day period. Systematic and ocular health information were tabulated. As expected, conditions commonly seen with sun exposure were the most prevalent. However, the incidence of macular degeneration was low. Due to poor access to health care in this area, there was a higher frequency of conditions not commonly seen in the American population at this mission.

Abstract: Branch Retinal Vein Occlusion (BRVO), Hemicentral Retinal Vein Occlusion (HCRVO), and Central Retinal Vein Occlusion (CRVO) represent the three anatomical types of vein occlusions that can occur in the retina. Two cases are presented to demonstrate these occlusions. The first case report discusses a patient who suffered bilateral, consecutive CRVOs and developed unilateral neovascular glaucoma, while the second details the findings of a patient who represented with a BRVO in one eye and a HCRVO in the other eye.

Abstract: A study was carried out to determine the reliability of digital tension to yield pressure measurements for children. Abstract: Eye care practitioners should be familiar with visual paraneoplastic syndromes as important indicators of possible carcinoma or cutaneous metastatic melanoma. Two cases are presented to demonstrate this. In case #1, a 59-year-old Caucasian male reported a sudden onset of shimmering photopsias and night blindness six years after the removal of a cutaneous melanoma from his lower back. In case #2, an 81-year-old Caucasian woman reported decreased visual acuity, reduced peripheral vision, and photopsias.

Abstract: The repeatability of aided LogMAR ETDRS VA was examined in myopic children participating in a multi-center clinical trial to evaluate test retest reliability and provide guidelines for determining a significant VA change. 469 myopic children were refracted without cycloplegia by certified examiners to determine the best subjective correction. Using an EDTRS chart, aided monocular acuity was determined with a modified ETDRS protocol. VA measures were repeated one month after enrollment in 111 children. Overall, LogMAR VA provided a reliable measure in children aged 6 to 11 years.

Abstract: A 54 year old female presented with a one week history of decreasing central vision in her left eye. Findings suggested and actively growing tumor. The risks, benefits, and complications from enucleation, plaque irradiation and transpupillary thermotherapy (TTT) were presented to the patient. After two sessions of treatment, the tumor appeared to be collapsed, suggesting arrested development.

Abstract: Relationships between contrast and reaction times for detection and recognition of low contrast ranges were studied. Abstract: A study was carried out to measure the correlation between levels of reduced visual acuity, and tests of functional performance related to visual acuity, specifically, functional reading speed, and functional hand use. The Prognosis Beliefs Scale (PBS) survey was administered to four subgroups. 434 surveys were either mailed or administered on site. 171 surveys were returned. Title: Alleviation of computer induced eye discomfort syndrome and associated lipid layer changes
Authors with affiliations: Korb, Donald R.
Abstract: The role of high periocular humidity (HPH) in alleviating computer induced eye discomfort syndrome (CIEDS) and the changes in lipid layer thickness (LLT) occurring with computer use in ambient and HPH was examined. CIEDS was created by performing the computer game Taipei. Eye comfort was graded on a 5 point scale at baseline prior to computer use, and at 10 minute intervals during Phases 1 and 2. Phase 1 required the subject to play Taipei for 40 minutes. Phase 2 was continuous for another 40 minutes except the subject wore swim goggles to create HPH. Analysis of the data revealed that CIEDS can be alleviated by HPH and is correlated to a decrease in LLT.

Abstract: An overview is given on the experiences gained in fitting three patients with pellucid marginal degeneration. The patients' habitual corrections included spectacle lenses, soft toric contact lenses, and no visual correction. The results of a survey of Diplomats of the American Academy of Optometry Cornea and Contact Lens Section augment the discussion.

Abstract: A case is presented that illustrates the ocular sequelae produced by the additive effects of low blood pressure and sudden caffeine cessation. The case also reviews the symptomatology, appropriate work up and treatment strategies to make this diagnosis of exclusion.

Affiliations: Nova Southeastern Univ, Ft. Lauderdale, United States
Authors with affiliations: Stephens, Cliff, Nova Southeastern Univ, Ft. Lauderdale, United States
Abstract: Anterior lenticonous is a rarely encountered ocular disorder associated with Alport's Syndrome. The case of a middle-aged black male who presented with a diagnosis of Alport's syndrome is presented. The bizarre appearance of anterior lenticonous is highlighted. The differential diagnosis of lens shape abnormalities is reviewed along with the clinical presentation of Alport's Syndrome.

Abstract: Subclavian steal syndrome is a hemodynamic phenomenon that occurs when an atherosclerotic plaque obstructs the subclavian artery proximal to the origin of the vertebral artery. This article presents the pathophysiology, diagnostic testing and evaluation of this hemodynamic phenomenon. In addition, the Optometrist's role in diagnosing and managing subclavian steal syndrome is discussed.

Title: Effect of vision therapy on myopia progression
Affiliations: Indiana Univ, Bloomington, United States
Authors with affiliations: Rainey, Bill B., Indiana Univ, Bloomington, United States; Goss, David A., Indiana Univ, Bloomington, United States
Abstract: A longitudinal study was performed to investigate the effect of vision therapy (VT) on myopia progression. Myopic children 5 to 13 years of age were randomly assigned to either a VT or a control group, both groups received single vision lenses. The children were followed for 1 to 3 years, manifest subjective refractions performed every 6 months, and cycloplegic autorefractions performed annually. In general, accommodative and vergence VT did not have any effect on progression rates of accommodative lag in myopic children.

Title: Testing the inhibitory effects of mascara life on bacterial growth in mascara
Affiliations: Illinois Coll of Optometry, Chicago, United States
Authors with affiliations: Gable, Eileen M., Illinois Coll of Optometry, Chicago, United States; Gabriel, Helen M., Illinois Coll of Optometry, Chicago, United States; Sauser, Kimberly A., Illinois Coll of Optometry, Chicago, United States; Rice, Jeanne A., Illinois Coll of Optometry, Chicago, United States
Abstract: A study was carried out to compare the effectiveness of mascara versus mascara with the addition of Mascara Life against the growth of Staphylococcus aureus>. To simulate three to six months of use, twelve tubes of Maybelline Great Lash mascara were dried for five consecutive days with the applicator wands removed. Mascara Life was added to the first set of six tubes and an equal amount of saline was added to a second set of six tubes. One tube from each set served as a control. The ten remaining tubes were inoculated with a standardized suspension of Staphylococcus aureus. Two calibrated samples from each tube were plated onto blood agar at 0, 1, 7, 14, 21 and 28 days after initial inoculation. The number of organisms was determined after 24 hours of incubation by the plate-count method. Data indicate that mascara alone is as effective as mascara with the addition of Mascara Life in retarding bacterial growth.
Index Keywords: Additives; Bacteria; Blood; Tubes (components); Bacterial growth; Eugonic broth; Incubation; Mascara; Nutrients; Plate count method; Staphylococcus aureus; Ophthalmology

Abstract: Myotonic Dystrophy is an autosomal dominant disease characterized by myotonia, distal weakness, and progressive muscular atrophy. Affiliations: Cincinnati Eye Inst, Cincinnati, United States
Authors with affiliations: Singh, Jason J., Cincinnati Eye Inst, Cincinnati, United States
Abstract: Metastatic breast cancer is the most common primary tumor metastasizing to the ocular structures. Ophthalmic manifestations include cranial nerve involvement, brain involvement with papilledema, Horner's syndrome, and choroidal and orbital tumors. This presentation will familiarize the clinician with the significance of anti-Ri antibody and its correlation with paraneoplastic syndromes.

Abstract: To determine the efficiency of the Dissuader device for security forces (SF), the Optical Radiation Branch of the Air Force Research Laboratory (AFRL/HEDO) attempted to measure such devices. Eight volunteer SF subjects were given an extensive laser eye examination before and after testing. Field tests determined day and night visibility thresholds and glare cobe effectiveness and sensitivity to night vision goggles (NVG). Results indicate that although the Dissuader laser beam is not bright enough for daytime tagging of an intruder, it is very effective at night for tagging or illuminating a target and as a glare source.

Abstract: A study was initiated to determine how accommodation can best be stimulated and measured to assess true and maximum accommodative amplitude. Several methods of stimulating accommodation were used and several objective and subjective methods of measuring accommodation were compared. Accommodation was stimulated with increasingly powered minus lenses, a Focometer, and 6% pilocarpine. A Hartinger Coincidence Refractometer, the Focometer, and subjective blur criteria were used to measure the induced accommodative amplitude.

Abstract: To determine the incidence of lens immobility with hydrogel disposable lenses and to monitor the time course of recovery of lens movement after eye-opening, 20 subjects, who had discontinued contact lens wear for a minimum of 24 hours, were fit with etafilcon A lenses of either -1.00D or -3.00D. The lenses were allowed to settle for a minimum of 30 minutes before lens movement in primary gaze was evaluated. Subjects then slept for 8 hours and lens movement was evaluated immediately on eye opening. Analysis of the data revealed that there is no correlation between conjunctival indentation or conjunctival staining and time to recovery of lens movement.

Abstract: A new method for classifying the genotypes of Pseudomonas aeruginosa isolated from contact lens wearers was assessed. Ten P. aeruginosa strains were analyzed. Pearson correlation was used to calculate strain similarity and unweighted pair group method using average linkages used for cluster analysis. All the strains showed multiple PCR products for each primer.

Abstract: Two cases of human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection and central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO) in middle-aged adults are presented. Immune complex deposition is the hypothesized causative factor of CRVO in HIV infected patients. The presentation of CRVO in young adult patients is uncommon, and HIV infection should be considered in the differential diagnosis.

Abstract: Wessely immune ring is the formation of a ring-shaped infiltrate in the corneal stroma that arises from a type 3 immune response involving antigen-antibody complex formation. The differential diagnosis of this condition is often difficult but is extremely critical. This article reviews the differential diagnosis and highlights a dramatic case having a sterile, CL-related etiology. It also details the indications for culturing and staining and portrays the methods and tests involved.

Abstract: Presented is an unusual case of optic neuritis secondary to prostate cancer metastasis. The case should inform the eye care professionals of the signs and symptoms associated with orbital metastatic tumors. The patient's optic disc photos, MRI studies, and bone scan are displayed and the clinical presentation, differential diagnosis as well as treatment and management options are presented.

Title: What's most important to soft lens wearers?
Affiliations: Johnson & Johnson Vision Care, Inc, United States
Authors with affiliations: Buch, John R., Johnson & Johnson Vision Care, Inc, United States
Abstract: To determine subjective aspects of lens handling and comfort that are considered most important to wearers of soft contact lenses, 83 subjects were asked to participate in a five-page survey as they entered the VISTAKON Research Clinic. The first page collected demographic and contact lens history data. Pages 2-4 collected data on lens handling and comfort. Detecting lens inversion and the ease of lens insertion were considered more important than the category of overall handling. Once on the eye, the majority of subjects want a lens that provides a soothing comfort throughout the day, not just initially or at the end of the day.

Affiliations: Cincinnati Eye Inst, Cincinnati, United States

Abstract: A 20-year-old male presented with a history of sulfuric acid burns to both eyes. The left eye was phthisical, while the right eye had severe corneal opacification and neovascularization with a visual acuity of count fingers at 2 feet. A keratolimbal allograft transplantation (KLAL) was performed on his right eye followed by penetrating keratoplasty and cataract extraction with IOL placement. Two and a half years after the initial surgery, his visual acuity is now 20/25.

Abstract: Discrepancies in reported symptoms between patients diagnosed with dry eye by the doctor and patients who think they have dry eye were evaluated. The Dry Eye Questionnaire (DEQ) and McMonnies' questionnaire were administered at six clinical sites to 1054 consecutive patients. The examining doctor, who was unaware of DEQ responses, evaluated each patient for dry eye. Data indicate that in making a diagnosis of dry eye, clinicians take into consideration all patient reported symptoms, while patients appear to only take the feeling of dryness into account when asked if they think they have dry eye.

Abstract: A direct, noninvasive measurement of tear oxygen tension behind soft contact lenses was developed. Abstract: A study was made to ascertain the level of knowledge and attitudes of optometrists regarding HIV/AIDS and to inform the development of a strategy for optometry to contribute in combating the disease. A self-administered structured questionnaire was mailed to selected practitioners. The areas investigated included knowledge of the disease, attitudes, practices and practitioner education. Analysis of the data revealed that there is a lack of knowledge among practitioners, resulting in inappropriate attitudes and fears. Majority of the respondents wanted to be better informed about HIV/AIDS and the preferred means selected was by Aids Education Booklets.

Abstract: The effect of examiner on the measurement of corneal oxygen shortfall associated with the wear of rigid gas permeable lenses was studied. Abstract: The effect of posture on the Pulsatile Ocular Blood Flow (POBF) was studied in 79 normal subjects with different refractive errors. The axial length was measured, followed by Perkins intraocular pressure (IOP) and POBF with an OBF tonometer at a sitting posture. The measurements of IOP and POBF were repeated at a lying posture. Both the POBF and PA were influenced by axial length, indicating that axial length should be measured in determining the POBF and PA.

Twenty subjects were selected for Low Vision (LV), Older Normal (ON) and Young Normal (YN) groups. Subjects viewed either a Bailey-Lovie distance letter chart or a chart containing rings of dots of decreasing diameter in a Bull's eye pattern. Subjects were asked to choose the 'clearer and darker' view on each JCC flip. An 'equal' response was allowed when no difference between the two views was observed. Although neither chart type nor NCC lens power had a significant effect on the ranges of uncertainty for cylinder axis and cylinder power, there were significant differences in the results due to age and visual acuity (subject group).

Abstract: A study was carried out to determine the frequency and intensity of common dry eye symptoms in patients diagnosed with Sjogren's syndrome (SS) and Keratoconjunctivitis sicca (KS). A total of 64 patients diagnosed with SS or KS responded to a mailed dry eye questionnaire (DEQ). The data were compared to a larger population of 687 unselected non-contact lens wearers (NCL) who filled the same questionnaire. SS and KS patients showed more frequency and intense dry eye symptoms than a group of unselected NCL patients. In both groups, symptoms shifted toward greater intensity in the evening.

Abstract: A prospective study of conductive keratoplasty for +0.75D to +3.00D of hyperopia was performed at multiple locations. Abstract: Elevation of intraocular pressure in response to a course of topical ocular steroid treatment is a frequently encountered complication. Abstract: A study was carried out to compare the distribution of refractive errors in albinos to persons with idiopathic congenital nystagmus (CN), who make similar movements but have better visual acuity. Abstract: As part of a Navy prospective clinical investigation on recovery from photo-refractive keratectomy (PRK), the postoperative corneal-healing process was modeled using Orbscan pachymetry. Accounting for diurnal variation, corneal thickness maps were obtained from 18 subjects prior to their PRK surgery, immediately after surgery, and weekly for 8 weeks thereafter. Abstract: A survey was sent to 300 randomly selected optometrists from across the United States asking about their use of the dilation reversal drop dapiprazole HCl. If they used it, an attempt was made to inquire which patients they use it on, how they administer it, and how patients respond to it. Those who do not use dapiprazole were asked why they do not. Abstract: Accurate saccadic eye movements are necessary for comprehension of written material. Digit naming tests are employed to assess oculomotor efficiency. An abnormal conjugate vertical elevation was noted as the patient performed the horizontal reading portion of the test. Abstract: Morning Glory Syndrome is a unilateral or bilateral congenital anomaly of the optic nerve. Abstract: To identify subjective reasons for noncompliance, a survey was mailed to 631 Standing Rock Sioux diabetics, asking for demographic information and degree of agreement with 11 statements. Agreement with these 11 reasons for noncompliance suggested depression, misunderstanding, lack of family support, or problems with the clinic, doctors or transportation. Abstract: The magnitude of the short-term (SF), homogeneous (Ho) and heterogeneous (He) long-term fluctuation (LF) in normal subjects and patients with glaucoma was studied using the HFA SITA-Standard and SITA-Fast algorithms. Abstract: Keratoconus is a non-inflammatory, progressive distortion of the cornea that results in high amounts of irregular corenal astigmatism and decreased visual acuity. This case reports a unilateral presentation of early keratoconus with the simultaneous onset of progressive axial myopia. Abstract: A study was performed to determine the effect of lens movement on distance and near visual acuity with bifocal and multifocal soft contact lenses. The right eye of eight subjects was fit with two different base curves, in three experimental multifocal soft contact lenses (center near, center distance and true multifocal). Abstract: A study was carried out to determine the predictability of lens prescription for Acuvue Bifocal contact lenses (BCL) and monovision (MCL). 100 participants, with no presbyopic contact lens experience were randomized into MCL and BCL with cross-over after 6 months. Another 50 successful MCL wearers were fitted and subsequent adjustments made according to the manufacturer's guide for BCL. It was found that more lenses are required for BCL and MCL prescription optimization and approximately equal numbers for the unsuccessful and successful wearers. Abstract: A survey was initiated to determine if there is a discrepancy between the recommendations from the American Optometric Association (AOA) and Oregon pediatricians regarding when a child should receive their first complete vision/eye examination. Anonymous surveys were sent out to 211 Oregon pediatricians listed with the Oregon Pediatricians Association. Two weeks later, reminder e-mails were sent to 150 pediatricians with available addresses. The survey showed that there is a discrepancy between the AOA's guidelines and Oregon pediatricians regarding when a child should receive their first complete vision system. It also proved that optometrists are underutilized by Oregon pediatricians in vision care referrals.

Abstract: The capability of current technologies in correcting higher order wavefront aberrations in the human eye with contact lenses was studied. Abstract: To determine the objective measurements and subjective ratings that initially discriminate between preference for monovision (MCL), Acuvue Bifocal contact lenses (BCL) or spectable lenses (SL), 50 successful monovision contact lens wearers wore BCL for 6 months. Abstract: In cases of nerve drusen difficult to identify by simple B-scan at low gain, the 'saturate above' option was used to filter out the reflections displayed for normal nerve tissues in the vicinity of the nerve drusen. Authors: Mansfield D., Beaton J., Bennett H.
Title: 'Glaucoma affecting each crystalline lens': A long-lost manuscript by Dr. William Mackenzie
Affiliations: Inverclyde Royal Hospital, Greenock, United Kingdom; Royal College of Physicians, Surgeons of Glasgow, Glasgow, United Kingdom; Tennent Institute, Gartnavel General Hospital, Glasgow, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Mansfield, D., Inverclyde Royal Hospital, Greenock, United Kingdom; Beaton, J., Royal College of Physicians, Surgeons of Glasgow, Glasgow, United Kingdom; Bennett, H., Tennent Institute, Gartnavel General Hospital, Glasgow, United Kingdom
Abstract: Dr. William Mackenzie was one of the great pioneers of British ophthalmology in the 19th century. We present a newly-discovered manuscript in which Mackenzie described how he performed surgery for bilateral nuclear sclerosis of the lens, in 1842-1843. This case became the focus for a discussion of the nature of 'cataract' and 'glaucoma' in the fourth edition of Mackenzie's great work, A practical treatise on diseases of the eye. Mackenzie is generally remembered as a great compiler of knowledge, but the text Mackenzie built around this case shows him pursuing original arguments based on his own observation. This case report gives us a vignette of Mackenzie that illustrates aspects of Mackenzie's character and achievements in an intimate way, and it dramatizes in a lively manner how some of the most fundamental concepts in ophthalmology evolved. Copyright (C) 2000 Elsevier Science Inc.
Author Keywords: Cataract; Glaucoma; Inflammation; Mackenzie, William

Abstract: The nurse's role in addressing ophthalmic emergencies can determine the urgency of the treatment and, in some cases, the final visual outcome. It is important to understand the spectrum of traumatic eye injuries so the patient will be better cared for and the appropriate treatment regimen will be started before permanent vision loss occurs. Assessing visual acuity is key; it must be documented, and if visual acuity cannot be obtained immediately, this fact also must be recorded.

Abstract: Many patients demonstrate a myopic refractive shift following Traumatic Brain Injury (TBI) or stroke. The clinical challenge is to provide immediate relief of clear distance vision while attempting to reestablish the baseline refractive error. Case reports are given that illustrate three primary courses for traumatic pseudomyopia: a transient state that ultimately resolves; a recalcitrant condition that relaxes under cycloplegia, but immediately returns as the cycloplegic wears off; and a less common subgroup that continues to increase in myopia over time.

Abstract: Using modern imaging technology, an attempt was made to determine whether the optic nerve head (ONH) is altered in early dementia of the Alzheimer type (DAT). Abstract: The effect of repeated sub-threshold UV exposure on PRK treated rabbit corneas was addressed. Abstract: A two-year prospective study was carried out to assess the effect of myopic defocus on the rate of childhood myopia progression. Ninety four myopic school children out of 106 aged between 9-14 years old completed the study. Subjects were randomly allocated to a myopic defocus (MD) group or a no defocus (ND) group. It was found that contrary to many animal studies, myopic defocus can speed up myopia development in already myopic humans.

Abstract: Vogt-Koyanagi-Harada Syndrome (VKH) is a rare condition accounting for less than 4% of uveitis referrals in the United States. Authors: Lang Amanda, Good Gregory
Title: Usage of 11 basic color terms during a color naming task for individuals with normal and defective color vision
Affiliations: Ohio State Univ, Columbus, OH, United States
Authors with affiliations: Lang, Amanda, Ohio State Univ, Columbus, OH, United States; Good, Gregory, Ohio State Univ, Columbus, OH, United States
Abstract: A study was carried out to determined how individuals with normal and defective color vision use 11 basic color terms to name samples from all areas of real color space. Thirty individuals with normal color vision used 11 basic color terms (red, orange, yellow, green, blue, purple, pink, brown, grey, white and black) individually or in combination to name samples from the Optical Society of America-Uniform Color Scales. Results indicate that individuals with color vision defects do not use all 11 basic color terms equally and those with a severe defect do not reliably use any of the 11 basic color terms.

Abstract: Epidural steroid injection is widely used in the management of chronic back pain. Retinal hemorrhages associated with this treatment are well described, but central serous chorioretinopathy (CSC) following this treatment has not been reported in the United States. A case of CSC following epidural steroid injection is presented. This case supports previous hypotheses that a resulting adrenergic reaction causes choroicapillaries permeability changes.

Title: Ocular prosthesis management in a pediatric patient

Abstract: Addressing ocular prosthesis management for a child, a case of a 2-year-old Hispanic male who had an enucleation at 3 months of age after a diagnosis of retinoblastoma in the left eye was considered. Four months after surgery, an ocular prosthesis was fit. Since the patient had no follow up care, prosthesis was found to be irritating and asymmetry occurred. To correct the problem, the patient was fit with a new prosthesis and polycarbonate spectacles. The new prosthesis was comfortable for the patient, cosmetically pleasing and allowed the conjunctivities to resolve.

Authors: Ma L., Chin L., Sarfaraz M., Shepard D., Li J., Yu C.
Title: An investigation of eye lens complication for gamma knife radiosurgery of trigeminal neuralgia
Source title: Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology - Proceedings
Affiliations: Department of Radiation Oncology, University of Maryland School of Medicine, 22 South Greene Street, Baltimore, MD 21201, United States; Department of Neurosurgery, University of Maryland School of Medicine, 22 South Greene Street, Baltimore, MD 21201, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ma, L., Department of Radiation Oncology, University of Maryland School of Medicine, 22 South Greene Street, Baltimore, MD 21201, United States; Chin, L., Department of Neurosurgery, University of Maryland School of Medicine, 22 South Greene Street, Baltimore, MD 21201, United States; Sarfaraz, M., Department of Radiation Oncology, University of Maryland School of Medicine, 22 South Greene Street, Baltimore, MD 21201, United States; Shepard, D., Department of Radiation Oncology, University of Maryland School of Medicine, 22 South Greene Street, Baltimore, MD 21201, United States; Li, J., Department of Radiation Oncology, University of Maryland School of Medicine, 22 South Greene Street, Baltimore, MD 21201, United States; Yu, C., Department of Radiation Oncology, University of Maryland School of Medicine, 22 South Greene Street, Baltimore, MD 21201, United States
Abstract: We report in-vivo dosimetry and phantom study results for determining complication rate of the eye lens for trigeminal neuralgia (TN) patients treated using gamma knife radiosurgery. This study is driven by the observation that a large dose such as 70-80 Gy was generally prescribed for trigeminal neuralgia, and, therefore, a small percentage (2-3%) of scattering dose to the lens of the eye could reach or even exceed its tolerance dose. In-vivo dosimetry measurements on six patients and a head phantom were performed to investigate these effects. The average lens dose was measured to be 0.077±0.006 Gy. This value is significantly lower than the 1-2% as predicated from the gamma knife treatment planning system. Using an empirical biological model, the probability of the lens complication was determined to be 0.1%. This low rate confirms our clinical findings that few TN patients develop cataracts.
Author Keywords: Gamma knife; Sterotactic radiosurgery; Trigeminal neuralgia
Index Keywords: Diseases; Dosimetry; Gamma rays; Mathematical models; Patient treatment; Radiation; Surgery; Tissue; Vision; Cataracts; Eye lens; Gamma knife radiosurgery; Sterotatic radiosurgery; Trigeminal neuralgia; Ophthalmology

Title: Advanced manual lensometry: a self-learning guide for evaluating multifocal and specialty lenses, progressive lenses, prisms, and rigid contact lenses.
Affiliations: Productivity Enhancement Group, Inc., Sarasota, Florida, United States
Authors with affiliations: Garber, N., Productivity Enhancement Group, Inc., Sarasota, Florida, United States
Abstract: Advanced manual lensometry techniques are required when automated lensometry may not be appropriate for reading special lenses or rigid contact lenses. These advanced techniques are challenging but provide accurate diagnostic and lens verification data. One should never assume that the glasses the patient is wearing match what the doctor prescribed. The prescription should be checked at least once, even when there are no patient complaints. If possible, learn and practice these special procedures under the supervision of an optician or ophthalmic clinical trainer. This will help to verify that you are performing these special techniques correctly.

Authors: Tasman W.
Title: Ensuring ophthalmologists are knowledgeable in the new millennium
Affiliations: Wills Eye Hospital, 900 Walnut Street, Philadelphia, PA 19107, United States
Authors with affiliations: Tasman, W., Wills Eye Hospital, 900 Walnut Street, Philadelphia, PA 19107, United States,
Abstract: In 1910 the Flexner Report on medical education elevated the status of medical education. This was followed in 1916 by the first examination of what was then to become the American Board of Ophthalmology, the first certifying Board in the United States. Since World War II there have been exponential advances in medicine and technology. Now, in the new millennium, computerized examinations, some of which are tailored to the abilities of the candidate, are the current state of the art. The next 10 to 20 years undoubtedly will see the development of technology-based simulation that may be able to evaluate cognitive skills and competence.

Authors: Lai C.-H., Lin K.-Y., Chiou Y.-Y., Sue Y.-J., Chen F.-F.
Title: Alport's syndrome: Clinical experience with five pediatric patients from two families
Affiliations: Department of Pediatrics, National Cheng Kung University Hosp., 138 Sheng Li Road, Tainan, Taiwan
Authors with affiliations: Lai, C.-H., Department of Pediatrics, National Cheng Kung University Hosp., 138 Sheng Li Road, Tainan, Taiwan; Lin, K.-Y., Department of Pediatrics, National Cheng Kung University Hosp., 138 Sheng Li Road, Tainan, Taiwan; Chiou, Y.-Y., Department of Pediatrics, National Cheng Kung University Hosp., 138 Sheng Li Road, Tainan, Taiwan; Sue, Y.-J., Department of Pediatrics, National Cheng Kung University Hosp., 138 Sheng Li Road, Tainan, Taiwan; Chen, F.-F., Department of Pediatrics, National Cheng Kung University Hosp., 138 Sheng Li Road, Tainan, Taiwan
Abstract: Objective: To gain information on the progression and manifestations of Alport's syndrome, as well as on the experience of treatment in the different patients. Materials and Methods: Five pediatric patients (four boys, one girl) with Alport's syndrome seen between 1993-1999 were included in this study. The clinical, histological, and genetic features as well as treatment were reviewed by medical records. Kidney biopsies were obtained from two patients. Results: Four patients were familial cases, and one male patient was a sporadic case. In the four boys, the first sign of the disease was hematuria. Proteinuria is variable, ranging from detectable in early stages to a nephrotic range in advanced stages. One patient with persistent nephritic range proteinuria went into renal insufficiency at the age of 8 years after being followed-up for 5 years. In the other boys, the symptomatology was limited to permanent hematuria and mild to heavy proteinuria. In the girl, the symptomatology was limited to permanent hematuria with mild proteinuria. The ophthalmologic evaluation failed to show lenticonus or macular flecks in our patients. Hearing impairment was noted in two boys at the age of 5 years. Conclusions: Patients with persistence of heavy proteinuria had a worse prognosis. Careful monitoring of renal function and early intervention for proteinuria are proposed for optimal preservation of kidney function.
Author Keywords: Alport's syndrome; Hematuria; Hereditary nephritis; Proteinuria
Index Keywords: cyclosporin; dipeptidyl carboxypeptidase inhibitor; prednisolone; steroid; Alport syndrome; article; female; hearing impairment; hematuria; human; kidney biopsy; kidney failure; male; ophthalmology; preschool child; prognosis; proteinuria

Authors: Bradley L.J., Riederer M.L.

Affiliations: 10-2630 Bourquin Cr. West, Abbotsford, BC V2S 5N7, Canada

Abstract: The Vision First Check Program was developed in consultation with ophthalmology and optometry representatives on the provincial Vision Advisory Committee and piloted by participating optometrists in four communities in BC between January and June 1998. This preschool vision screening program provides for one vision screening for children aged two and three at no cost to the family or the Medical Services Plan of BC. The screening is by optometrists, the marketing of the program is coordinated through public health, and the data collection is coordinated through the Medical Services Plan as a no-fee item.
